channel.title: Skype bought out by Microsoft
channel.description:
http://www.businessinsider.com/microsoft-buying-skype-2011-5
Microsoft has bought Skype for $8.5 billion in cash, Anupreeta Das and Nick Wingfield of the WSJ report. The deal was concluded late Monday evening. It is one of the biggest acquisitions Microsoft has ever made. The price tag is silly on a stand-alone basis, but the deal could make strategic sense for Microsoft: With the rise of Facebook and Gmail and Apple, the company has lost its dominance of online communications. Although Skype's functionality is now a commodity (Microsoft has services that offer the same functionality), Skype's user-base and "social network" are not. If Microsoft can successfully integrate Skype with Exchange and Microsoft's other communications tools (including Windows Phone 7), it would give users more incentive to stick with its products. And $8.5 billion is chump change for Microsoft. The deal is a nice flip for Silver Lake, Andreessen Horowitz and other firms that bought 65% of Skype from eBay at a valuation of $2.75 billion two years ago. It also puts $1.9 billion in the pockets of Skype's founders. And eBay shareholders, who still owned 35% of the company, didn't do badly, either. (eBay ended up making nice money on Skype.)

item.title: Skype bought out by Microsoft
item.dc:creator: @akl akl
item.description:
@akl wrote:

[quote=“Holic, post:15, topic:394477”][quote author=akl link=topic=491663.msg3595633#msg3595633 date=1305051919]
This is actually great for Facebook
[/quote]
Explain[/quote]
Well, since Microsoft is an investor in the company, it gains access to Skype’s assets and without spending a single cent it’s able to keep away Google from incorporating and buying out Skype and gain an even larger stronghold on the communication platform on the internet.
Facebook has, in a way, eliminated serious competition that the Google Skype fusion could pose.

Read full topic

item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

runescape3dude:

I don’t know why noone likes msn messenger, call me old fashioned but its not bad.

messenger tends to force completely useless updates that do nothing but awkwardly change the gui around and then forces you to use said update

gimmicks aside the only good msn update was offline messaging, everything I need can be done with windows messenger(the really old one!)

EDIT: and what’s with people hating on skype just because of this? it has always been terrible

item.title: Skype bought out by Microsoft
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“zachera, post:16, topic:394477”][quote author=tL link=topic=491663.msg3595564#msg3595564 date=1305045318]
Skype for Linux says what?
[/quote]Microsoft will be supporting Skype’s non-Windows platform development (Mac OS X, Linux, Android, etc), I have read.[/quote]

Them supporting Mac OS X is a given, since they already have quite a big Mac OS X team at Microsoft, and do make some rather good Mac OS X applications now (especially with Office 2011). As for phone platforms, like Android and iOS that is something Microsoft are into too - since they’ve made apps for them too (at least iOS, i haven’t looked for Android).

But Linux, I don’t know, maybe I’ve missed it, but have Microsoft ever shown any support for Linux? Maybe they would be obligated to continue to support as part of the buyout, but even that could be a period of time.

Read full topic

item.title: Skype bought out by Microsoft
item.dc:creator: @Unlimited1 .Unlimited
item.description:
@Unlimited1 wrote:

More on it here: http://www.engadget.com/2011/05/10/microsofts-acquisition-of-skype-for-8-5-billion-becomes-offici/

Xbox and Kinect support are explicitly mentioned in the announcement of this definitive agreement, as is Windows Phone integration -- both the gaming and mobile aspects being presumably key incentives for Microsoft to acquire Skype. Importantly, this purchase shouldn't affect Skypers outside of the Microsoft ecosystem, as Steve Ballmer's team promises to continue "to invest in and support Skype clients on non-Microsoft platforms." A new Microsoft Skype Division will now be opened up to accommodate the newcomers, with current Skype CEO Tony Bates becoming president of that operation and reporting directly to Ballmer.

I wonder what will become of Skype and if its features will be brought else where besides Xbox/Kinect and Windows Phone.

Read full topic

item.title: Skype bought out by Microsoft
item.dc:creator: @cumescape cumescape
item.description:
@cumescape wrote:

Business Insider

Microsoft Has Bought Skype For $8.5 Billion

And why not?

Microsoft has bought Skype for $8.5 billion in cash, Anupreeta Das and Nick Wingfield of the WSJ report.

The deal was concluded late Monday evening.

It is one of the biggest acquisitions Microsoft has ever made.

The price tag is silly on a stand-alone basis, but the deal could make strategic sense for Microsoft: With the rise of Facebook and Gmail and Apple, the company has lost its dominance of online communications. Although Skype’s functionality is now a commodity (Microsoft has services that offer the same functionality), Skype’s user-base and “social network” are not. If Microsoft can successfully integrate Skype with Exchange and Microsoft’s other communications tools (including Windows Phone 7), it would give users more incentive to stick with its products.

And $8.5 billion is chump change for Microsoft.

The deal is a nice flip for Silver Lake, Andreessen Horowitz and other firms that bought 65% of Skype from eBay at a valuation of $2.75 billion two years ago. It also puts $1.9 billion in the pockets of Skype’s founders. And eBay shareholders, who still owned 35% of the company, didn’t do badly, either. (eBay ended up making nice money on Skype.)

Read full topic
